title: Jose Mourinho plays down Manchester United's chances of signing players from Premier League rivals
text:
Sport Jose Mourinho plays down Manchester United's chances of signing players from Premier League rivals The top flight's financial climate has changed and Mourinho knows he can't have it all his own way in the transfer window Share Jose Mourinho knows United can't dominate the transfer market like they used to (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Share Get Manchester United FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
Jose Mourinho has played down Manchester United's chances of signing any players who currently play for the club's Premier League rivals. 
United's Portuguese boss believes the financial climate has changed in the top flight and United no longer possess the monetary might to pluck the best players away from rival teams in England. 
In the past United were able to force other clubs' hands with successful swoops for Michael Carrick and Dimitar Berbatov from Tottenham in 2006 and 2008 respectively. 
Sir Alex Ferguson also convinced Robin van Persie to move from Arsenal to United in 2012 and that season he fired them to the title. Robin van Persie joined United from Arsenal in 2012 (Photo: Getty) Mourinho has played down United's chances of signing any players from their rivals (Photo: REUTERS) 
Mourinho doesn't think such signings are possible these days given the vast amounts of money raked in by all 20 Premier League clubs. 
The United manager told France Football: "Here (in England), everyone is powerful now. 
"The scenery has changed. If I want to buy a player from Tottenham, I canâ€™t. Nor can I buy a player from Manchester City or Arsenal. 
"That was not the case before. At Chelsea, I brought in Shaun Wright-Phillips, who was the best player at Manchester City or Ashley Cole from Arsenal. 
"Sir Alex, when he wanted the best player from Tottenham, he bought Michael Carrick and then Berbatov." Like us on Facebook
